user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of detect_process_cpu_core_count:
```c
static unsigned int
detect_process_cpu_core_count (void)
{
  unsigned int num_proc_cpu_cores;
  unsigned int sys_cpu_cores;
  int res;

  sys_cpu_cores = get_cpu_core_count ();
  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count ();
  if (0 > res)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Cannot detect the number of logical CPU cores available "
             "for this process.\n");
    if (1 != sys_cpu_cores)
      printf ("Assuming all %u system logical CPU cores are available to run "
              "threads of this process.\n", sys_cpu_cores);
    else
      printf ("Assuming single logical CPU core available for this process.\n");
    num_proc_cpu_cores = sys_cpu_cores;
  }
  else
  {
    printf ("Detected %d logical CPU core%s available to run threads "
            "of this process.\n", res, (1 == res) ? "" : "s");
    num_proc_cpu_cores = (unsigned int) res;
  }
  if (num_proc_cpu_cores > sys_cpu_cores)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: Detected number of CPU cores available "
             "for this process (%u) is larger than detected number "
             "of CPU cores on the system (%u).\n",
             num_proc_cpu_cores, sys_cpu_cores);
    num_proc_cpu_cores = sys_cpu_cores;
    fprintf (stderr, "Using %u as the number of logical CPU cores available "
             "for this process.\n", num_proc_cpu_cores);
  }
  return num_proc_cpu_cores;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: This function has no parameters (detect_process_cpu_core_count(void)), so MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified) is not applicable here. All variables in the fragment are local (num_proc_cpu_cores, sys_cpu_cores, res) and may be assigned/modified without violating Rule 17.8. Calls to get_cpu_core_count() and mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count() are invoked with no arguments; any parameter handling inside those functions is outside the provided code and would need review in their own definitions. The printf/fprintf calls and the cast (unsigned int)res do not modify any function parameter. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation for Rule 17.8.
